Effects of temperature and concentration on rheological behavior of MWCNTs/SiO2(20–80)-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant☆
Mohammad Hemmat Esfe a,⁎, Masoud Afrand b, Wei-Mon Yan c,⁎, Hooman Yarmand d, Davood Toghraie a, Mahidzal Dahari e
a Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Khomeinishahr Branch, Islamic Azad University, Isfahan, Iran b Department of Mechanical Engineering, Najafabad Branch, Islamic Azad University, Najafabad, Iran c Department of Energy and Refrigerating Air-Conditioning Engineering, National Taipei University of Technology, Taipei 10608, Taiwan, ROC d Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Malaya, 50603 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia e Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Malaya, 50603 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

27 T E D PIn this work, effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on rheological behaviors of MWCNTs/SiO2–SAE40hybrid nano-lubricantwere examined. The experimentswere performed at the temperatures ranging from25 °C to 50 °C and solid volume fractions of 0%, 0.0625%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1%, 1.5% and 2%. Measured results indicated that the nano-lubricant exhibit Newtonian behavior at the solid volume fraction up to 1% and it is nonNewtonian for solid volume fractions of 1.5% and 2%. Viscosity measurements also showed that the viscosity decreases with increasing temperature and rises with an increase in the solid volume fraction. Finally, the empirical correlationwith acceptable accuracy has been proposed to predict the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants. © 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd. Keywords: Rheological behavior Hybrid nano-lubricant SiO2 MWCNT

U N C O
R R E C 1. Introduction
Nanofluids are fluid suspensions of nanometer-sized particles of metals, oxides, carbides, nitrides or nanotubes. They have attracted much attention due to their high thermal conductivity and thermal performances compared to base fluids. In recent decades, applications of nanofluids have been developed in different thermal systems such as engine cooling, heat exchangers, cooling of electronic devices, solar energy and so on [1–4]. Adding nanoparticles into common fluids (water, ethylene glycol and oil) can be altered the thermo-physical properties of them. The thermal conductivity and viscosity of nanofluids are two key parameters for heat and mass transfer phenomena. The thermal conductivity of several types of nanofluids containing metal, metal oxide nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes has been investigated by many researchers [5–9]. These investigations revealed that adding the nanoparticles significantly improves the thermal conductivity of nanofluids, which leads to enhance the heat transfer rate.
Theoretical studies on the viscosity of liquid suspensions were performed by Mooney [10], Brinkman [11], Batchelor [12], Drew and Passman [13], andWang et al. [14]. Moreover,measurement of viscosity
76

ffects of temperature and con ass Transf. (2016), http://dx.
was performed by many researchers [14–22]. These studies revealed that the viscosity of nanofluids is a function of temperature, concentration, particle size, and type of particles and base fluid.
In recent years, a new class of nanofluids has been attentive, which is called hybrid nanofluids. Many researchers have investigated experimentally the properties of these nanofluids. For example, thermophysical properties of hybrid nanofluids such as Cu/Al2O3–water [23], MWCNT/SiO2–water [24], MWCNT/Ag–water [25], Ag/TiO2–water [26], MWCNT/Fe2O3–water [27], Cu/TiO2–water [28], DWCNT/ZnO– water/EG [29], SiO2/MWCNT–water/EG [30], ZnO/TiO2–EG [31], and Fe3O4–Ag/EG [32] have been performed in details.
Engine oil containing a small amount of nanoparticles is called a nano-lubricant. This nano-lubricant is prepared for highly loaded components. Engine oils have attracted the interest of researchers owing to several applications. In this regard, Vakili-Nezhaad et al. [33] reported the effects of multi-walled carbon nanotubes on the viscosity index of lube oil cuts. Vasheghani et al. [34] studied the effects of Al2O3 on the enhancement of thermal conductivity and viscosity of nanofluids in engine oil. Thermal and rheological properties of oil-based nanofluids from different carbon nanostructures were also examined by Ettefaghi et al. [35,36].
Previous works showed that many researches on the dynamic viscosity of nanofluids containing various kinds of solid particles were performed. Moreover, only a few works have been performed on the thermo-physical properties of engine oils. However, the viscosity of the MWCNT/SiO2–-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant has not been

examined. In the present study, the effects of temperature and concentration on rheological behaviors of the MWCNTs/SiO2–-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant are investigated. Moreover, a new experimental correlation is proposed to estimate the dynamic viscosity of theMWCNT/SiO2– SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant.

E C
2. Nanofluid preparation
In this work, a two-step method was used to prepare the nanofluid samples (0%, 0.0625%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1%, 1.5% and 2% vol.). To achieve a characterization of the sample, the structural properties of the dry MWCNTs and SiO2 nanoparticles were measured by using X-ray diffraction, as shown in Fig. 1. The particles containing 20% volume of MWCNT and 80% volume SiO2 were dispersed in engine oil (SAE40). To prepare the stable samples, suitable mechanisms such as mixing and sonication were used. In this way, after magnetic stirring for 2 h, the samples were exposed to an ultrasonic processor (Hielscher Company, Germany). The photograph of all samples is displayed in Fig. 2.
U N C O
R R
E D P
R O 3. Dynamic viscosity measurement
The dynamic viscosity of the MWCNT/SiO2–-SAE40 hybrid nanolubricants with solid volume fractions of 0.0625%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1%, 1.5% and 2.0% were measured at the temperature range of 25 °C to 50 °C. The CAP 2000+ viscometer (Brookfield Engineering Laboratories, Inc.) was used for the measurements. This viscometer is medium to high shear rate instruments with Cone Plate geometry and integrated temperature control of the test sample material. Experiments were carried out in the rotational speed range of 100 to 500 500 rpmRPM. In this work, cone 01 which can measure the viscosity in the range of 20 to 2000 mPa.s was used. The range of accuracy and repeatability of the viscometer are ±2.0% and ±0.5%, respectively. All experiments were repeated at different rotational speed for each solid volume fraction and temperature.
4. Results and discussion
The nanofluids consist of engine oil (SAE40), MWCNT (ID=3–5 nm and OD= 5–15 nm) and SiO2 nanoparticles with average diameter size
of all samples.

of 20–30 nm. The measurements were performed at the temperature range of 25 °C to 50 °C for several samples at solid volume fraction ranges from 0% to 2.0%.
U N C O
R R E C T
P R O
O F
4.1. Comparison between experimental results and theoretical models
To predict the viscosity of the nano-lubricants, the Batchelor equation of viscosity [10] and the Wang model [13] presented in Eq. (1) and Eq. (2) were used.
μnf μbf ¼ 1þ 2:5φþ 6:2φ2 ð1Þ
μnf μbf ¼ 1þ 7:23φþ 123φ2 ð2Þ
where μ is the dynamic viscosity and φ is the solid volume fraction. Moreover, the subscripts nf and bf indicate the nanofluid and base fluid, respectively. Fig. 3 demonstrates the comparison between measured viscosity ratios and predicted results from both models. It can be seen that both traditional models are not appropriate for predicting the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants. Moreover, it is observed that a higher deviation is noted for a case with a higher solid volume fraction.
4.2. Rheological evaluation
The dynamic viscosity of the nanofluid affects the Prandtl number and Reynolds number. These are very important for the pumping power, heat and mass transfer. To evaluate the rheological behavior of the nanofluid, the viscosity of nanofluid samples was measured at

different rotational speeds (different shear rates). Fig. 4 shows the evolution of the dynamic viscosity as a function of rotational speeds (different shear rates) for a range of temperature from 25 to 50 °C and for solid volume fractions of 0, 1%, 1.5% and 2%. It is seen in Fig. 4 that the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant decreases with an increase of temperature. Besides, at solid volume fractions of 0% and 1%, the measurements show little variation in dynamic viscosity with an increase in rotational speed. This indicates that the nano-lubricant exhibit a Newtonian behavior at solid volume fraction up to 1%. But for the results at solid volume fractions of 1.5% and 2%, rotational speed (shear rate) would affect the dynamic viscosity of the nanolubricant. This behavior is due to shear heating effects that occur in high rotational speed. Therefore, the nano-lubricant behaves a nonNewtonian fluid at solid volume fractions of 1.5% and 2%,
4.3. Effects of temperature and solid volume fraction
Fig. 5 presents the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant versus solid volume fraction at different temperatures. Measured results showed that the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant rises with increase in the solid volume fraction. For lower temperature, the enhancement is more sensitive than that at higher temperature.
Please cite this article as: M.H. Esfe, et al., Effects of temperature and con hybrid nano-lubricant, Int. Commun. Heat Mass Transf. (2016), http://dx.
E D P
R O
O F To understand the variation of the dynamic viscosity with temperature, the dynamic viscosity versus temperature at different solid volume fractions are depicted in Fig. 6. The results reveal that the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant decreases with increasing temperature with a similar trend. This variation in higher solid volume fractions is more tangible. In fact, at higher solid volume fractions, the interactions between the nanoparticles may be affected by temperature. It is observed that the maximum enhancement of dynamic viscosity of the MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants is 30.2%. This occurred at the solid volume fraction of 1.0% and temperature of 40 °C.
5. New correlation
To estimate the viscosity ratio of the MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants, a new trustworthy correlation using the experimental results is proposed. The general form of the correlation is as follows:
μnf μbf ¼ a0 þ a1φþ a2φ2 þ a3φ3 ð3Þ
where, μ is the dynamic viscosity and φ is the solid volume fraction in %. Moreover, nf and bf indicate nanofluid and base fluid, respectively. a0, a1, a2 and a3 are the constant value, which are listed for each temperature in Table 1.
To evaluate the accuracy of the correlation the deviation margin is analyzed. The margin of deviation between experimental data and predicted values can be calculated as below.
Deviation ¼ μnf μbf Exp − μnfμbf Pred

U N C O6. Conclusion
In the present study, the effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on rheological behavior of the MWCNTs/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant were examined. The viscosity measurements were performed under different temperatures ranging from 25 °C to 50 °C and solid volume fractions ranging from 0% to 2%. The results revealed that traditional models are not appropriate for predicting the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants. The measurements at various shear rates showed that the nano-lubricant exhibit a Newtonian behavior at solid volume fraction up to 1% and it is nonNewtonian for solid volume fractions of 1.5% and 2%. The viscositymeasurements also showed that the viscosity decreases with increasing temperature and enhanceswith an increase in the solid volume fraction. Based on experimental data, viscosity ratio revealed that the maximum enhancement of viscosity of the nano-lubricant was 30.2%. Finally, the empirical correlation has been suggested to predict the viscosity of the MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants. The maximum deviation value was 1.2%. The comparison between the measurements and the correlation outputs showed that the suggestedmodel has an acceptable accuracy.
Please cite this article as: M.H. Esfe, et al., Effects of temperature and con hybrid nano-lubricant, Int. Commun. Heat Mass Transf. (2016), http://dx.

metadata.abstractText: 19 Available online xxxx 20 21 22 23 24 25 26 27 T E D P In this work, effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on rheological behaviors of MWCNTs/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricantwere examined. The experimentswere performed at the temperatures ranging from25 °C to 50 °C and solid volume fractions of 0%, 0.0625%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1%, 1.5% and 2%. Measured results indicated that the nano-lubricant exhibit Newtonian behavior at the solid volume fraction up to 1% and it is nonNewtonian for solid volume fractions of 1.5% and 2%. Viscosity measurements also showed that the viscosity decreases with increasing temperature and rises with an increase in the solid volume fraction. Finally, the empirical correlationwith acceptable accuracy has been proposed to predict the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/SiO2–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants. © 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
